position.marginalia_text: Pla[e]runq[ue] vnius anni consulatu, plus gestum seriorum negotiorum, egregiorumq[ue] facinorum, quàm tota vita maximorum Regum: exceptis admodùm paucis; Cyro, Philippo, Alexandro, Pyrrho; Agesilao, Euagora, Eumene; Jugurtha, Mithridate: alijs perpaucis. Olim plus virtutis, minus fama[e]: hodie plus fama[e], minus virtutis. Egregiè Romanus Poeta, ex ipsius Ca[e]saris disciplina: breue, et irreparabile tempus, Omnibus est vita[e]: sed Famam extendere Factis, Hoc Virtutis opus.

X-ref.text: famam extendere factis, hoc virtutis opus

marginalia.translation: In a consulate of one year generally more serious business and excellent deeds are accomplished than in the entire life of the greatest kings, with very few exceptions: Cyrus, Philip, Alexander, Pyrrhus, Agesilaus, Evagoras, Eumenes, Jugurtha, Mithridates, and extremely few others. Once there was more virtue, less fame; today there is more fame, less virtue. Based on the discipline of Caesar himself, the Roman poet put it brilliantly: "the course of life is brief and cannot be recalled: but virtue’s task is this, to increase fame by deeds" [ trans. Kline]. Your word, my deed.

position.marginalia_text: Scire Gra[e]ca[e], Romanaeq[ue] historia[e]; continuatam seriem, valde conducit polyhistori. Herodotus historiam suam est orsus à fine prophetarum: Thucydides à fine Herodoti: Xenophon à fine Thucydidis. Romanae historiae primam partem praecipue suscepit Halicarnasseus; professus eam se historiam velle producere vsq[ue] ad initium primi belli Punici. Secundam partem antèa suscepit Polybius. Postèa Liuius tertiam potissimùm partem explicare voluit. Tacitus non procul à fine Liuij suos Annales orditur: Marcellinus à fine Taciti, id est, à principatu Nerua[e]: vt Herodianus ab exitu M. Antonini, in quo desijt Dion. Nec est difficile, talia continua[e] successionis exempla in alijs pla[e]risq[ue] historicis obseruare.

marginalia.translation: It is tremendously profitable for the polyhistor to know the continuous line of Greek and Roman history. Herodotus began his history from the end of the prophets; Thucydides from the end of Herodotus; Xenophon from the end of Thucydides. Dionysius of Halicarnassus took up the first part of Roman history in particular, declaring he wanted to record history up to the beginning of the first Punic war. Before, Polybius took on the second part. Afterwards Livy wanted to give an account of the third part especially. Tacitus begins his Annals not far from the end of Livy. Marcellinus from the end of Tacitus, namely from the principate of Nerva, just as Herodian starts from the death of Marcus Antoninus, where Cassius Dio stopped. And it is not hard to notice such examples of continued succession in most of the other historians.

position.marginalia_text: Duo autem Romana[e] historia[e] doctissimi, et diligentissimi scriptores, Dionysius, et Liuius. Quod attinet ad res, et tempora, Dionysij antefero diligentiam: verba à Liuio malo repetere, et sententias. Neq[ue] enim minima historia[e], ipsiusq[ue] iurisprudentia[e] Romana[e] pars, visq[ue] sita est in ipsis formulis; quas vbiq[ue] Liuius diserte recitat, atq[ue] adeo religiosè: Dionysius, et reliqui Gra[e]ci sua lingua exprimere non possent, né si vellent quidem maximè. Vnde Politicum decet, in primisq[ue] iurisconsultum, Liuiana[e] phrasis maximè omnium esse obseruantem: vt postèa Tacitea[e]. In qua Romana[e] prudentia[e], et fortitudinis; temperantia[e] etiam, et iustitia[e] proprius quidam vigor, visq[ue] neruosa, viuidiùs mihi videtur efflorescere, adeóq[ue] fertiliùs maturescere. Doctor Gentilis totus est Liuianus: vt Lipsius ferè Taciteus. Ambo sapiunt: sed vterq[ue] coniunctus, varieq[ue] coagmentatus plus valeret. Ta[e]det omnis sine varietate excellentia[e]: et philosophi est, plura bona paucioribus anteponere.

marginalia.translation: Yet the two most learned and assiduous writers of Roman history [are] Dionysius and Livy. In regard to the subject and the times I esteem Dionysius’ attentiveness more highly; I prefer to repeat the words and thoughts of Livy. For in these very formulas lies quite a big part of Roman history and of jurisprudence itself, which Livy recites dexterously and indeed religiously. Dionysius and the other Greeks could not have expressed them in their language, even if they had very much wanted to do so. And for this reason it is appropriate for the politician, and especially the lawyer, to be attentive most of all to Livy’s diction, just like afterwards to that of Tacitus. In this a particular vitality and powerful force of Roman prudence and courage, of restraint also and of justice seems to me to flourish in quite a lively way, and indeed to come to maturity in a very fruitful manner. Doctor Gentili is completely of Livy, just as Lipsius more or less of Tacitus. Both are wise, but each of them is stronger when connected and in various ways fastened together. Without variety every form of excellence makes weary, and it is the task of the philosopher to place a greater quantity of excellence before a smaller one.
